case_name: Bihta Co-operative Development Cane Marketing Union Ltd. v. Bank of Bihar Ltd.

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 699 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 699 of 1964. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated April 14, 1961 of Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 162 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 14, 1961 of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 162 of 1955.

facts.text: Suit filed in 1951 by two plaintiffs: Bihta Co-operative Development Cane Marketing Union Ltd. and its Secretary.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was instituted by the two plaintiffs against seven defendants... The second plaintiff was a Secretary of the Union at the time when the suit was filed in 1951.

facts.text: Bihta Co-operative Development Cane Marketing Union Ltd. is a society registered under the Bihar and Orissa Co-operative Societies Act, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: The first appellant, Bihta Co-operative Development Cane Marketing Union Ltd. hereinafter referred to as the Union is a society registered under the Bihar and Orissa Co-operative Societies Act, 1935

facts.text: Under Resolution dated 16th April, 1947 of Executive Committee, defendant No. 6 Babu Lal Varma (Joint Secretary) and defendant No. 7 Ram Janame Varma (Treasurer) jointly authorised to withdraw moneys from Bank of Bihar Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Under a Resolution dated the 16th April, 1947 of the Executive Committee of the Union, the defendant No. 6, Babu Lal Varma, Joint Secretary of the Union and Ram Janame Varma, defendant No. 7, the Treasurer of the Union, were jointly authorised to withdraw moneys

facts.text: Union had a running account with Bank of Bihar Ltd. (defendant No.1).

anchor.surface_text: with which it had a running account. On the 26th of May, 1948, defendant No. 6 and defendant No. 7 went to the bank

facts.text: On 26th May 1948, defendant No.6 and No.7 went to bank to encash cheque on behalf of Union, learned funds insufficient.

anchor.surface_text: On the 26th of May, 1948, defendant No. 6 and defendant No. 7 went to the bank to encase a cheque on behalf of the Union and then they came to learn that the funds in the account

facts.text: On 16th April 1948, Rs. 11,000 withdrawn from Union's account by spurious cheque not from Union's cheque book.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on the 16th of April, 1948 a sum of Rs. 11,000/- had been withdrawn from the said account by means of a cheque which did number companye out of the cheque book of the Union

facts.text: Spurious cheque was loose cheque form surrendered by ex-constituent issued on 23rd March 1948, converted purporting signatures of def6 and def7.

anchor.surface_text: and that a loose cheque form surrendered by an ex-constituent of the bank issued to someone on the 23rd March, 1948 had been companyverted into a cheque purporting to bear the signatures of defendant No. 6 and defendant No. 7.

facts.text: Spurious cheque bore signature of defendant No.7 but purported signature of defendant No.6 was forgery, found at trial.

anchor.surface_text: It is number necessary to state the facts in detail and it will be sufficient to numbere that the spurious cheque bore the signature of defendant No. 7 but the purported signature

facts.text: Criminal proceedings started, five defendants including Nos. 3,4,5 (bank employees), 6 and 7 tried and acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal proceedings were started and five defendants including defendants Nos. 6 and 7 were put on trial. Defendants Nos. 3, 4 and 5 were employees of the defendant-bank. Ultimately, however, all the accused were acquitted.

facts.text: Suit against seven defendants: 1 Bank of Bihar Ltd., 2 Manager, 3-5 employees, 6 Babu Lal Varma, 7 Ram Janame Varma.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was instituted by the two plaintiffs against seven defendants, all of whom have already been mentioned except the second defendant who was the Manager of the Bank

facts.text: Subordinate Judge decreed suit against defendants 1,2,4,5,7 jointly, found cheque forged, 4,5,7 conspired to withdraw Rs.11,000 fraudulently.

anchor.surface_text: A large number of witnesses were examined and the Subordinate Judge came to the companyclusion that the cheque in question was a forged and fabricated document and that defendants 4, 5 and 7 acting in companylusion and companyspiracy with one another had withdrawn the sum of Rs. 11,000/-

facts.text: Subordinate Judge found insufficient evidence against defendants 3 and 6.

anchor.surface_text: He, however, thought that there was numbersufficient evidence against defendants 3 and 6

facts.text: Defendants 1 and 2 appealed to Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: and passed a decree as against defendants 1, 2, 4, 5 and 7 jointly. Defendants 1 and 2 only went up in appeal to the Patna High Court.

facts.text: Patna High Court agreed with Subordinate Judge that defendants 4,5,7 parties to conspiracy for withdrawal of Rs.11,000.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court agreed with the finding of the Subordinate Judge that defendants 4, 5 and 7 were parties to the companyspiracy resulting in the withdrawal of the sum of Rs. 11,000/-

facts.text: Patna High Court absolved defendant No.2 from liability on ground of negligence.

anchor.surface_text: but absolved the defendant No. 2 from any liability on the ground of negligence.

facts.text: Patna High Court found no negligence or lack of reasonable precaution on part of Union.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, on an examination of the evidence, found itself unable to hold that there was any negligence or lack of reasonable precaution on the part of the Union.

facts.text: Patna High Court held Ram Janame Varma (def7) may have been party to conspiracy but Union not negligent thereby.

anchor.surface_text: It further held that Ram Janame Varma may have been a party to the companyspiracy which culminated in the withdrawal of the money through the disputed cheque, but the Union companyld number be said to be negligent

facts.text: Patna High Court allowed bank's appeal on ground of lack of civil court jurisdiction under s.48(1) and s.57 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Having found in favour of the plaintiffs on the merits of the case, the High Court allowed the appeal of the bank on the ground that the jurisdiction of the civil companyrt was ousted

facts.text: Jurisdiction point not taken in written statement of any defendants.

anchor.surface_text: This point was number taken in the written statement of any of the defendants.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside Patna High Court judgment and restores Subordinate Judge decree, except no decree against respondent No.7.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal succeeds, the judgment of the Patna High Court is set aside and that of the Subordinate Judge restored. The appellants do number want a decree against respondent No. 7.

facts.text: Appellants before Supreme Court are the plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants before this Court are the plaintiffs.

facts.text: Contestants: Bank of Bihar Ltd. (def1), Madan Mohan Pandit (def2), Babu Lal Varma (def6).

anchor.surface_text: The only companytesting respondents are the Bank of Bihar Ltd., Madan Mohan Pandit and Babu Lal Varma defendants 1, 2 and 6 in the suit .

facts.text: Bank sought liable as trustee for Union, abused trust by gross negligence allowing embezzlement.

anchor.surface_text: The bank was sought to be made liable on the ground that it was a trustee for the Union and had abused the trust by allowing the amount in question to be embezzled through its gross negligence.

s. 48 1  read with S. 57 of the Bihar and Orissa Co-operative Societies Act, 1935. Broadly speaking, s. 48 1  enumerates disputes between certain classes of persons and or the societies registered under the Act which have to be referred to the Registrar of Co- operative Societies for adjudication and S. 57 1  provides that numbercivil companyrt shall have jurisdiction in respect of any dispute required by s. 48 1  to be so referred.

concepts.interpretation: Enumerates specific disputes touching business of society that must be referred to Registrar, ousting civil court jurisdiction; does not cover dispute between society and non-member non-financing bank.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, necessary to, set out the relevant portion of s. 48 1  which reads as follows- 48.  1  If any dispute touching the business of a registered society  other than a dispute regarding disciplinary action taken by the society or its managing companymittee against a paid servant of the society  arises-  a  amongst members, past members, persons claiming through members, past members or deceased member and sureties of members, past members or deceased members, whether such sureties are members or number-members or  b  between a member, past member, persons claiming through a member, past member or deceased member, or sureties of members, past members or deceased members, whether such sureties are members or number-members, and the society, its managing companymittees or any officer, agent or servant of the society or  c  between the society or its managing companymittee and any past or present officer, agent or servant of the society or  d  between the society and any other registered society or  e  between a financing bank authorised under the provisions of sub-section  1  of section 16 and a person who is number a member of a registered society such disputes shall be referred to the Registrar Provided that numberclaim against a past member or the estate of a deceased member shall be treated as a dispute if the liability of the past member or of the estate of the deceased member has been extinguished by virtue of section 32 or section 63. Explanation- 1  A claim by a registered society for any debt or demand due to it from a member, numbermember, past member or the numberinee, heir or legal representative of a deceased member or number-member or from sureties of members, past members or deceased members, whether such sureties are members or number- members, shall be a dispute touching the business of the society within the meaning of this sub-section even in case such debt or demand is admitted and the only point at issue is the ability to pay or the manner of enforcement of payment.

concepts.interpretation: Limited to disputes in clauses (a)-(e); Explanation does not add new categories or cover all non-member disputes; requires specific parties like members, officers, financing banks.

issues.text: The main question in this appeal is, whether the suit out of which this appeal arises was entertainable by a civil court, in view of the provisions of s. 48(1) read with S. 57 of the Bihar and Orissa Co-operative Societies Act, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: The main question in this appeal is, whether the suit out of which this appeal arises was entertainable by a civil court, in view of the provisions of s. 48 1  read with S. 57 of the Bihar and Orissa Co-operative Societies Act, 1935.

holdings.text: The suit was entertainable by the civil court as the dispute is not covered by s.48(1) read with s.57 of the Bihar and Orissa Co-operative Societies Act, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: The main question in this appeal is, whether the suit out of which this appeal arises was entertainable by a civil court, in view of the provisions of s. 48(1) read with S. 57 of the Bihar and Orissa Co-operative Societies Act, 1935. Broadly speaking, s. 48(1) enumerates disputes between certain classes of persons and or the societies registered under the Act which have to be referred to the Registrar of Co- operative Societies for adjudication and S. 57 provides that no civil court shall have jurisdiction in respect of any dispute required by s. 48(1) to be so referred.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dispute touches business of society but does not fall within specific categories in clauses (a)-(e) of s.48(1); Bank of Bihar not a financing bank under clause (e); Explanation does not enlarge scope but harmonises with main provision.

holdings.text: The dispute does not come under any of the heads in sub-clauses (a) to (e) of s.48(1).

anchor.surface_text: It will be noticed that not all disputes in which a registered society may be involved are within the mischief of the section. Assuming that the dispute in this case touches the business of the Union which is a registered society, the question is is it one which comes under any of the heads mentioned in sub-cls. (a) to (e) of the sub-section? Sub-cl. (a) has no operation if one of the disputants is the society itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause (a) inapplicable as society is disputant; (b) requires non-member to be surety; (c) requires officer/agent/servant; (d) between societies; (e) requires financing bank, which Bank of Bihar is not.

holdings.text: The first Explanation to s.48(1) does not widen the scope to include claims by societies against non-members outside clauses (a)-(e).

anchor.surface_text: The question then arises whether the first Explanation to the section widens the scope of sub-s. (1) of s. 48 so as to include claims by registered societies against non-members even if the same are not covered by clause (e). ... The Explanation must be read so as to harmonise with and clear up any ambiguity in the main section. It should not be so construed as to widen the ambit of the section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explanation clarifies admitted debts as disputes but does not add new categories; must harmonise with main section; 1948 amendment adding 'non-member' due to clause (e), not to expand; follows Sagauli Sugar Works precedent.

holdings.text: The bank is liable to the plaintiff society for paying on a forged cheque due to its negligence.

anchor.surface_text: Having found in favour of the plaintiffs on the merits of the case... Not only was there negligence on the part of the banker in not ascertaining whether the signatures on the cheque were genuine, the circumstances attending the encashment of the cheque show conclusively that the banker was negligent and some of its officers fraudulent right from the beginning.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cheque with forged signature is nullity, no mandate to pay; bank negligent in verification and encashment circumstances suspicious; accepts lower court findings on forgery and conspiracy of bank employees.

holdings.text: Negligence or blameworthiness of the customer society does not bar recovery when a signature on the cheque is forged.

anchor.surface_text: As the customer and the banker are under a contractual relation in this matter, it appears obvious that in drawing a cheque the customer is bound to take usual and reasonable precautions to prevent forgery. ... If the signatures on the cheque or at least that of one of the joint signatories to the cheque are not or is not genuine, there is no mandate on the bank to pay and the question of any negligence on the part of the customer... would afford no defence to the bank.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes London Joint Stock Bank (negligence in cheque drawing before signature); forged signature means no mandate, post-signature negligence irrelevant; cites Halsbury that forged cheque is nullity absent adoption/estoppel.

holdings.text: The judgment of the Patna High Court is set aside and that of the Subordinate Judge restored, except no decree against respondent No.7.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal succeeds, the judgment of the Patna High Court is set aside and that of the Subordinate Judge restored. The appellants do not want a decree against respondent No. 7.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Errors in High Court on jurisdiction corrected; merits correctly found in favour of plaintiffs by both lower courts; appellants concede no decree against No.7.

precedents.citation: Sagauli Sugar Works Private Ltd. v. Assistant Registrar, Co-operative Societies, Motihari Others 1

anchor.surface_text: Sagauli Sugar Works Private Ltd. v. Assistant Registrar, Co-operative Societies, Motihari Others 1 . In that case, there was a dispute between the appellant, a companypany registered under the Indian Companies Act and a society. registered under the Act.

precedents.case_name: Sagauli Sugar Works Private Ltd. v. Assistant Registrar, Co-operative Societies, Motihari & Others
precedents.cited_proposition: History of legislation regarding co-operative societies Act and interpretation of s.48(1) and Explanation; claims by registered society against non-member not within s.48 unless financing bank under cl.(e)
precedents.cited_holding: The Explanation cannot be read as adding a new head to the categories a to e under s.48(1); addition of non-member does not enlarge scope to all disputes with non-members

anchor.surface_text: He referred us to the judgment of the House of Lords in London Joint Stock Bank, Limited v. Macmillan Arthur 1  in support of his argument.

precedents.case_name: London Joint Stock Bank Limited v. Macmillan & Arthur
precedents.cited_proposition: Customer bound to take usual and reasonable precautions to prevent forgery when drawing a cheque; negligence in drawing cheque making forgery easy causes loss to customer
precedents.cited_holding: If cheque drawn facilitating forgery, customer bears loss; negligence must be in the transaction itself

anchor.surface_text: Attempts have often been made to extend the principle of Young v. Grote, 4 Bing. 253 beyond the case of negligence in the immediate transaction, but they have always failed.

precedents.cited_proposition: Principle of negligence in the immediate transaction of drawing cheque

anchor.surface_text: The main question in this appeal is, whether the suit out of which this appeal arises was entertainable by a civil court, in view of the provisions of s. 48(1) read with S. 57 of the Bihar and Orissa Co-operative Societies Act, 1935. Broadly speaking, s. 48(1) enumerates disputes between certain classes of persons and or the societies registered under the Act which have to be referred to the Registrar of Co- operative Societies for adjudication and S. 57 provides that no civil court shall have jurisdiction in respect of any dispute required by s. 48(1) to be so referred.
In the result, the appeal succeeds, the judgment of the Patna High Court is set aside and that of the Subordinate Judge restored. The appellants do number want a decree against respondent No. 7. C

It will be noticed that not all disputes in which a registered society may be involved are within the mischief of the section. Assuming that the dispute in this case touches the business of the Union which is a registered society, the question is is it one which comes under any of the heads mentioned in sub-cls. (a) to (e) of the sub-section? Sub-cl. (a) has no operation if one of the disputants is the society itself.
In the result, the appeal succeeds, the judgment of the Patna High Court is set aside and that of the Subordinate Judge restored. The appellants do number want a decree against respondent No. 7. C
anye within the purview of the main section 48 1 . The addition of the word number-member by the Amending Act of 1948, to the First Explanation has nu

edges.explanation: Holding h3 that first Explanation does not widen scope directly addresses issue i3 of whether Explanation widens scope of s.48(1) to include claims against non-members.

anchor.surface_text: The question then arises whether the first Explanation to the section widens the scope of sub-s. (1) of s. 48 so as to include claims by registered societies against non-members even if the same are not covered by clause (e). ... The Explanation must be read so as to harmonise with and clear up any ambiguity in the main section. It should not be so construed as to widen the ambit of the section.
In the result, the appeal succeeds, the judgment of the Patna High Court is set aside and that of the Subordinate Judge restored. The appellants do number want a decree against respondent No. 7. C

anchor.surface_text: Having found in favour of the plaintiffs on the merits of the case... Not only was there negligence on the part of the banker in not ascertaining whether the signatures on the cheque were genuine, the circumstances attending the encashment of the cheque show conclusively that the banker was negligent and some of its officers fraudulent right from the beginning.
In the result, the appeal succeeds, the judgment of the Patna High Court is set aside and that of the Subordinate Judge restored. The appellants do number want a decree against respondent No. 7. C

anchor.surface_text: As the customer and the banker are under a contractual relation in this matter, it appears obvious that in drawing a cheque the customer is bound to take usual and reasonable precautions to prevent forgery. ... If the signatures on the cheque or at least that of one of the joint signatories to the cheque are not or is not genuine, there is no mandate on the bank to pay and the question of any negligence on the part of the customer... would afford no defence to the bank.
In the result, the appeal succeeds, the judgment of the Patna High Court is set aside and that of the Subordinate Judge restored. The appellants do number want a decree against respondent No. 7. C
